oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Robin Lee Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Robin Lee (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Robin Lee; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie directs Robin Lee for the Robin Lee radio spot on the Music City Album Review -- (00:14) Collie directs Lee to stress the ease of being a disc jockey for radio spot -- (00:34) Collie directs Lee to announce her album for the Music City Album Review radio spot -- (00:56) Collie directs Lee to announce her album for the Music City Album Review radio spot -- (01:01) Collie directs Lee to announce that she is with the 'Biffer' on the Music City Album Review -- (01:12) Collie has Lee spell out Biff Collie and it takes Lee a couple attempts -- (01:42) Collie attempts to say his and Lee's names in a form of pig-Latin -- (02:28) Collie has Lee introduce her favorite artist, Dolly Parton, to introduce "Yellow Roses" -- (02:47) Collie has Lee reflect on Parton for a radio spot -- (03:05) Collie directs Lee to announce the thirty-minute radio spot -- (03:11) Collie directs Lee to announce a recap radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (03:25) Collie helps Lee's diction for her Music City Album Review radio spot -- (03:32) Collie has Lee ask the audience if they had been paying attention -- (03:42) Collie and Lee joke about giving away lee's ear rings -- (04:07) Collie directs Lee to announce that she is with the 'Biffer' on the Music City Album Review -- (04:17) Collie has Lee announce the commercial break radio spot -- (04:30) Collie has Lee announce the return from commercial break radio spot -- (04:36) Collie directs Lee to question the show quality for radio spot -- (04:40) Collie directs Lee to tell Collie to take the week off for radio spot -- (04:50) Collie jokes about Lee's seriousness in last radio spot -- (04:55) Collie directs Lee to announce the thirty-minute remaining radio spot -- (05:00) Collie directs Lee to announce that she is with Collie on the Music City Album Review radio spot -- (05:16) Collie directs Lee to give her personal signature for radio spot -- (05:51) Collie has Lee give her leaving radio spots -- (06:16) Collie directs Lee to give the radio spot for the next week's program -- (06:38) Collie directs Lee to give her goodbye radio spot -- (07:03) Collie tells Lee about the procedures of the Music City Album Review -- (07:42) Lee introduces the album title Black Velvet and the title track "Black Velvet;" Lee discusses how "Black Velvet" had been a success in Canada for Alannah Myles -- (08:23) Lee asserts "Black Velvet" to be a recognized track; additionally, Collie and Lee compares Lee to Myles in her music video -- (09:10) Collie and Lee discuss the meaning of Myles' phrase 'When you play it, say it' -- (09:55) "How About Goodbye" is told by Lee to be a representation of a female summizing her relationship -- (10:50) Collie recalls discussions with Vern Gosdin about Gosdin's ex-wife -- (12:01) Lee recalls how she was having issues getting songs to record when she found "He's Helping Me Get Over You" -- (13:31) Collie addresses how titles are created and recalls a friend of his that had a peculiarly way of saying known phrases -- (15:03) Collie and Lee discuss how "When the Feeling Comes Around" was a Jennifer Warnes song that she had to sell the idea to her producer -- (16:06) Lee reminisces about how "When the Feeling Comes Around" feels like a 'beach song' -- (16:22) Collie and Lee address Ron Reynolds' contribution and how he uses Nerds containers for percussion -- (18:22) Collie and Lee discuss how Pam 'Sunny' Russ has her first song cut on the Black Velvet album -- (19:36) Collie has Lee recall being in Panama City, Florida the first time she heard one of her songs being played -- (20:30) Collie and Lee attempt to express the feeling when no one is around when he has something to tell -- (21:44) Collie tells about his daughter seeing Skip Ewing downtown and wanting to address him -- (22:33) Lee recalls a time working at the bank when a country celebrity walked in -- (22:52) "Love Letter" is told by Lee to be a 'boogie song' that she had recorded after "Black Velvet" had been cut -- (23:51) Collie and Lee discuss the importance of running in Lee's life -- (25:08) Collie has Lee discuss "Something I Know I'm Gonna Love" and Lee reveals the song's tie to Deborah Allen -- (26:42) Collie has Lee reflect on Lee's favorite artists and Lee reflects on owning a variety on music -- (28:01) Lee discusses how the piano is her instrument of choice -- (28:44) Collie describes how his poodle is terrified of thunderstorms and Collie and Lee reflects on crying dogs -- (29:46) "Every Little Bit Hurts" writer Tommy Brasfield is revealed to have passed away and Lee compares it to "Midnight Hour" -- (30:43) Lee reveals how "Till I Get It Right" was almost the title track as a demonstration of people's assumptions and Lee reveals how the album was changed to be primarily male backup singers -- (32:29) Collie and Lee discuss miniature buses that they use for travel -- (33:04) Collie introduces Lee and Lee tells how "Sad Eyes" was recorded for her first album originally -- (34:33) Lee reveals her paranoia when it comes to releasing singles -- (35:27) Collie and Lee show their appreciation for each other -- (35:45) Collie brings up the format of the show and Lee discusses her assumptions made pre-interview -- (36:57) Collie has Lee discuss how she wishes to go for a run -- (37:32) Collie tells Lee he will call her parents and tell them what she wants for dinner
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Lee, Robin (Singer); Collie, Biff;
